text: Hey everyone, welcome and thanks for

developer relations team and my

their questions about gameplay systems,
investigating the bugs, submitting
engine fixes, and also posting articles

because I want to show some examples of
how you can use gas as a designer after
you've gone through the initial setup
with code to set up gas in your project.
Now,
gas is a framework that really helps you
to develop your gameplay content in a
modular and datadriven way. Now, those
are some some often used buzzwords. So,
I'm going to show you how this can be
done to make your gameplay modular. It's
useful for both single player and
multiplayer games, and it's used in all
of Epic's games as well as many of your
games. It's a plugin that you can enable
in the editor by enabling the gameplay
abilities plugin.

some fans. So, people that will use gas

gas contains gameplay attributes and
tags and attributes are useful to man
manage your numbers. tags are used to
manage like your character state like
are they uh is your character alive or
dead, slowed, stunned, silenced and so
on.
And but also for uh assigning categories
to your assets like is a buff a fire

type? Um is it a slow effect? Is it a
freeze effect? It can also be used to
like send signals between systems and to
use a tag to like represent what kind of
signal it is. Now, gameplay effects are
really to define like which attributes
and which tags to apply to to an actor.
So, what to do with an actor. It can
also be running some logic like your
damage logic. And then there's then
there's abilities which really define
when something should happen. So, when
do I apply a game effect to an actor or
when do I uh trigger something else? It
can be when you press a button, but it
can also be uh driven by animation
timing or when something else happens in
gameplay.
